Award.AbstractNarration:
Deep learning, first proposed in 1989, still represents the most effective means for extracting specific information from large datasets. This approach exploits many nonlinear processing layers to develop representations of data at increasing levels of abstraction. Deep learning has demonstrated best-in-class performance in a range of applications, including image and speech recognition, and demonstrated promising results for tasks based on natural language understanding and translation. Crudely speaking, deep learning acquires ¡®knowledge¡¯ by tuning large numbers (¡Ý200) of fitting parameters during a supervised learning phase. These parameters are then used to extract information from previously ¡®unseen¡¯ data. Ultimately, deep learning is premised on using a large number of tuning parameters to develop nonlinear feature detectors capable of efficiently representing the intrinsic structure of the data at an abstract level.¡±

This project will examine two potentially powerful, but highly speculative alternative approaches to extract information from data. These approaches exploit the intrinsic properties of the data rather than an extensive set of tuning parameters. Both approaches are based on conjectures made by the PIs regarding possible extensions of techniques successfully applied in very different branches of mathematics. The first concerns the extraction of specific structural information from random sightings of objects; the second, forecasting the behavior of dynamical systems [6]. The ultimate goal of this project is to determine whether the aforementioned algebraic topological approaches or techniques developed for the forecasting of high-dimensional time-series or some variations thereof, can be exploited to create a new class of non-iterative unsupervised learning algorithms. The broader impact of the project is the training of young scientists at the hitherto unexplored intersection of abstract mathematics and machine learning, with possible applications in science,
technology, and commerce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pattern formation is ubiquitous in physical, biological, and engineered systems, ranging from molecular systems, to engineering- and geophysical-scale flows, among many examples. Research in mathematics, statistics, computer science, and related fields, coupled with our ever-increasing capability to acquire and process data, has spawned powerful tools able to decompose signals into pairs of characteristic temporal and spatial patterns. Yet, many signals are not readily separable into patterns existing solely in time or space. An efficient means of representing such signals would substantially enhance our ability to capture and analyze many complex phenomena.

This project combined dynamical systems theory with geometrical machine learning to develop a new data-driven framework, called Vector-valued Spectral Analysis (VSA), for extracting coherent spatiotemporal patterns generated by complex systems. This technique is based on the realization that a spatiotemporal signal can be viewed as a vector-valued observable of an underlying dynamical system; that is, an association of each state of the dynamical system (input) to a spatial pattern (output). This perspective allows one to decompose the signal into characteristic spatiotemporal patterns using a class of machine learning algorithms for vector-valued data. Importantly, VSA does not impose a separable spatial-temporal structure on the recovered patterns, and is thus capable of representing signals of far greater generality and physical interpretability than conventional approaches. We have studied, through rigorous mathematical analysis, the properties of this decomposition, and shown that it can reveal the intrinsic timescales of the dynamical system generating the data, while eliminating unwanted redundancies when that system exhibits symmetries. We have also demonstrated the efficacy of our approach with applications to prototype models exhibiting spatio temporal chaos, as well as identification of the El Ni?o phenomenon in spatiotemporal climate data.

Representative patterns recovered from VSA from a chaotic spatiotemporal signal, along with a comparison with the patterns recovered through a conventional technique, the Principal Components Analysis (PCA), are displayed in the attached image. In each panel, the horizontal and vertical axes correspond to space and time, respectively. Colors indicate the values of the raw signal (Panel a), or the recovered spatiotemporal patterns (Panels b-i). The VSA pattern in Panel (b) captures a large-scale structure associated with translation symmetry of the Kuramoto-Sivashinsky model. The patterns in Panels (c, d) capture smaller-scale waves embedded within the large-scale structures in Panel (b). The VSA patterns cannot be described in terms of individual pairs of spatial and temporal patterns. In contrast, the PCA patterns in Panels (e-i) exhibit a separable space-time behavior, which is not representative of the spatiotemporal structure of the signal.

Results from this project have applications across disciplines dealing with spatiotemporal data, including climate dynamics and molecular dynamics, and are thus expected to benefit the spectrum of human activities that depend son these disciplines. The project also contributed to the training of two early-career scientists from STEM-underrepresented groups.
